title: 114_hr2003
content: The Act is titled the "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" and it pertains to the distribution of death information by the Social Security Administration. The "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" amends Section 205(r) of the Social Security Act to require the Commissioner of Social Security to transmit information on deceased individuals to ensure completeness, timeliness, and accuracy, with safeguards to protect the information. The Commissioner of Social Security must implement safeguards to protect information on deceased individuals when sharing it with federal or state agencies administering federally funded benefits or programs, including the Do Not Pay system. Agencies must reimburse the Commissioner for the costs associated with this arrangement. The Commissioner of Social Security must ensure the protection of information on deceased individuals shared with federal agencies for purposes such as operating the Do Not Pay system. Agencies must reimburse reasonable costs for this arrangement. Under the Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012, agencies can compare death information from the Commissioner of Social Security with personally identifiable information to prevent improper payments, carry out tax administration, or for debt collection purposes. The Commissioner of Social Security can share information on deceased individuals with federal policing agencies for crime prevention and investigation purposes. Similar arrangements can be made with states for state-funded programs or retirement systems. The Commissioner of Social Security can share information on deceased individuals with federal and state agencies for statistical purposes and research activities, subject to safeguards for unauthorized use or disclosure. The amendments made to the Social Security Act and the Internal Revenue Code allow for sharing information on deceased individuals for statistical purposes and research activities, with safeguards in place. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to replace references to the Secretary of Health and Human Services with the Commissioner of Social Security. Additionally, a report to Congress on alternative sources of death data is required. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review alternative sources of death data for use by Federal agencies, analyzing accuracy, interoperability, accessibility, cost, security, and reliability. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review alternative sources of death data for Federal agencies, analyzing accuracy, interoperability, accessibility, cost, security, and reliability, and submit a report to Congress within 4 years. Social Security benefits will continue beyond the repeal date of the amendments. The Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012 is amended to improve the use of data by government agencies to curb improper payments, including the use of death data. The Office of Management and Budget will issue guidance to agencies on improving data matching with death databases for beneficiaries and annuity recipients within 6 months of the enactment of the section. The Office of Management and Budget will develop a plan to assist states, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations in providing records related to individual deaths to the Federal Government within 1 year of enactment. This includes recommendations for statutory changes or financial assistance. The plan may recommend statutory changes or financial assistance to ensure electronic provision of records by States, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations. It may also suggest appropriations or funding for implementation. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with relevant Federal agencies and stakeholders, will submit a report to Congress within 270 days on improving data matching for payments to deceased individuals. The heads of relevant Federal agencies, in consultation with States, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations, must submit a plan to Congress to enhance data matching for deceased individuals receiving federally funded benefits. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will provide annual reports on the implementation of this plan for five years, including recommendations. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will provide annual reports with recommendations on data matching for deceased individuals receiving federally funded benefits. Definitions for 'Indian tribe' and 'tribal organization' are as per the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. SEC. 4. PLAN FOR ENSURING THE ACCURACY AND COMPLETENESS OF DEATH DATA MAINTAINED BY THE SOCIAL SECURITY ADMINISTRATION. The Commissioner of Social Security, in consultation with the Secretary of Commerce, must submit a plan to Congress within 90 days of the enactment of this Act. The plan aims to ensure the accuracy and completeness of death data maintained by the Social Security Administration, including individuals not receiving benefits. Elements of the plan include identifying elderly individuals still alive according to records and improving policies for data accuracy. Improved policies and procedures are needed to verify the accuracy of death data maintained by the Social Security Administration. This includes identifying errors in records, such as individuals wrongly listed as dead or alive, and implementing a process for statistical analysis of death data. The Social Security Administration needs to improve its policies for verifying death data accuracy. This involves identifying errors in records and implementing statistical analysis to estimate the number of erroneous records. Legislation recommendations are also included. The Commissioner of Social Security must implement the plan within 2 years of the Act's enactment.
